title: How many refugees and migrants will arrive in Europe by sea in 2017?
preds: The number will more likely be in the 10s of thousands.
Figures now well within that range and  with winter months approaching, an upsurge is not likely.

I'm adding a slight chance of over 300,000 on the basis that the agreement to block migrants from leaving Libya for the sea crossing may be falling apart. What if a flood of migrants enter the Mediterranean, headed for Europe? Source: In August, the number of boats reaching Italian shores decreased considerably thanks to Italian funding going to militias attempting to stifle migrants and refugees leaving Libyan shores. But it was an attempt at a quick fix from Italy, as hundreds, if not thousands of migrants and refugees became stuck in eastern Sabratha under terrible conditions, while tensions simmered between human smugglers and the militias suppressing the smuggling. After a month of suppressing human smuggling, the al-Ammu militia allegedly clashed with smugglers trying to move boats filled with aspiring travelers. “Pushed by the European Union and Italy, the GNA in Tripoli granted legitimacy to Brigade 48 and al-Ammu. And their rivals — [a group called] the Operations Room and al-Wadi — deemed that unacceptable,” Harchaoui said, noting that “the LNA provided military help.” On Sept. 17, a paramilitary force attacked al-Ammu’s militia, kicking off a battle that left nearly 100 people dead and many more wounded in addition to the destruction of houses and other vital infrastructure. The LNA-backed Operations Room now controls Sabratha. “Said differently, Italy interfered. It altered a fragile equilibrium, and the Hifter camp seized the opportunity to make advances,” Harchaoui said. And now, a couple of weeks after the conclusion of a battle that dragged in all of Libya’s major actors, analysts say Italy’s troubling influence may have further destabilizing effects on Libya. Harchaoui added, “What I expect in the coming weeks is a backlash from all those anti-Hifter factions once they have regrouped and merged forces. I expect ugly battles in that same area between Ras Jdir and Tripoli, perhaps along the littoral or perhaps further inland, in the Nalut district. It is not going to be an uninterrupted series of rosy victories by the LNA, I don't think so.” Italy will likely continue to work with both the GNA and LNA, looking for the simplest solutions to complex problems. Italy is set for parliamentary elections in 2018, and immigration is the leading issue for the nation. The battle in Sabratha stemmed from the Italian government’s attempts to curtail immigration, and despite the destruction and loss of life, it may still be a political victory for a group of politicians and parties who seemingly have little interest in the life or well-being of refugees and migrants. “The coming weeks will tell whether the new group in control of Sabratha is effectively curtailing the flows,” Mattia Toaldo, a Libya expert and policy fellow at the European Council on Foreign Relations, told Al-Monitor. She explained, “Last year, October was one of the months with the highest flows, and so far 3,000 [people] have already arrived.”
 -- http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2017/10/libya-italy-pay-militias-stop-smuggling-migration.html
Too close to end of year.  This one most likely over.

The easing situation in Iraq and Syria are causing falling numbers of arriving refugees from Middle East. But there are many from Africa (Libya, Eritrea and more), problably Afghanistan and Pakistan (though they have a critical status). EU's treaties with Libyan organizations may reduce the number of arriving people from Africa and the route from Turkey over Bulgaria or Black Sea is not save as Eastern European countries (Visograd) strongly oppose any refugees in their countries.

Even if in news we see not much, how much of them really comes... I think its a secret information about xxxxxxxx refugees that comes. Europe is now full of them, and now only more and more of terrorists, because nobody really interested to check 100% their documents.

A very interesting article in the latest Economist says one reason for the relatively low number of mediterranean migrants this year is that smugglers make more money shipping petrol: http://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21728687-one-reason-smugglers-make-more-money-shipping-petrol-why-number?frsc=dg%7Ce

The figure now stands at 127.000. Only a massive new influx can get it above 300.000. Maybe a big fall out between Germany and Turkey after the German elections could trigger that. But even then it would take time and probably not count as "arrive by sea".
Switching to 100 from 97, unless something totally insane happens this year there's just not enough time to get past 300,000.

Moving 1% for less than 100k since we have already passed that number and are now at 121k.
Might increase 5% on 500k-750k depending on what happens this month.
http://data2.unhcr.org/en/situations/mediterranean
Second bucket up 5% following http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/546302 Still wonder about the Aegean and Erdogan.

Yearly figures from the website http://data2.unhcr.org/en/situations/mediterranean are as follows: 2014: 216,350
2015: 1,015,953
2016: 363,425
2017 YTD: 110,475 The spike in 2015 was mainly triggered by Syrians. I assume that most people who had the chance to leave Syria and come to Europe have tried it by now. Hence, the refugees now arriving in Europe probably mostly come from African countries, like before the Syrian crisis. Therefore, I put more weight on the 2014 and 2016 figures. The refugees figures for months August-December in 2014 and 2016 have been 113,037 and 106,032 respectively. Both numbers added to 110,475 end up in the range of 100,000-300,000.
Presumably this means "arrive alive"; still well below 300k projected.

Shifting toward 100-300k as the year is more than half over and only 100k have arrived so far. Arrivals tend to peak between Aug and Oct and it should be absolutely shocking if numbers returned to the 2015 peak.
People have now heard that the grass is not greener on the other side of the fence, which is now taller and has a narrow gate.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-europe-migrants-spain-idUSKBN19S150
This seems to be about routes, not volume.  They'll probably get over 200,000 but not close to 300,000 on current trend, unless Something Very Bad--that is, even worse than now--happens.
Just too much geopolitical pressure on Italy and other nations.
Sea arrivals in 2017 are 98,185.Last updated 03 Jul 2017. Only 6 months in the year left.

There's been a recent  upsurge in migrant arrivals  by sea (especially in Italy), but at present (and allowing that June's figures are not yet finalised), but at present UNHCR are recording 96,956 arrivals since Jan 2017. 
By comparison: the first six months of 2016: 231,133 arrivals (year end total 362,753)
first six months of 2015: 147,259 arrivals (year end total 1,015,078). It is unlikely that (unless some enormous unforeseen development that leads to the creation of masses of refugees - potentially the death of Pres. Bouteflika of Algeria could lead to such a set of circumstances) another 2015-style upsurge will occur imminently- the "open borders" policies in place at that time in Europe have been modified fairly drastically.  Additionally, there have been discussions in Italy about making access to its ports by illicit migrants much harder (given its length of coastline it is questionable how well this could be policed), but the political will in Europe is less welcoming than it was in 2015. Although one lesson from the 2015 and 2016 figures is that end-June figures may not be indicative of year-end figures...

From the available data we could conclude that 2017 is a ''normal" year, with a prognosis of 168.160 arrivals. The limit of 300.000 was  broken in ''normal" year 2016 but that was because in the first months the situation was still exceptional, though declining. So we should opt for the second possibility: [100.000 - 300.000 [ with a small probability for the third interval.

At least eight people died after a boat carrying refugees sank in the Mediterranean Sea on Saturday, Italian Rainews24 TV channel said, Anadolu reported. The boat was off Libya when it capsized, killing at least eight refugees while 100 others were missing, according to channel. Separately, a written statement by local coast guard command said 650 refugees on Saturday were recovered during 12 separate rescue operations on the Mediterranean, covering an area between Italy and Libya. According to latest International Organization for Migration figures, Mediterranean refugee arrivals reached 60,521 so far this year, with over 80 percent arriving in Italy while 1,530 refugees died in 2017 trying to reach Europe via the sea.
http://allafrica.com/stories/201706120142.html

COMMENT:  Very difficult to forecast this question without feeling guilty of the privilege of being born on the right side of the water.
Sea Arrival as of June 12  =  75,044  we are now entering the favorable season for these trips, and there are six more months to go.

1. I'm really sorry about USA Today's webpage format, but the below link claims only 73k have come by sea in the first half this year.
2. Seasonally, the highest months for migration are the fall which is still to come, but right now we can reasonably see the "Floor" as ~146k. In order to make it over the 300k "ceiling" there would need to be 123k more migrants in the next 6 months. That may have been probable last year, but I don't see the signs of an influx given the humanitarian crisis this year. https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2017/06/13/united-nations-figures-show-big-drop-number-migrants-arriving-europe/102806878/#
https://data2.unhcr.org/en/situations/mediterranean

2017 arrivals.  a very precursory look can give a linear prediction  2015 cannot easily recur for multiple reasons: depleted stocks of the most likely and motivated to come. 
Sharply reduced willingness to accept them
Learning curve on multiple methods to block arrivals. 
Massive public attitude change, that will help block arrivals forcefully if a crisis happens.

Safe zones in Southern part of Syria should be implemented. Egypt is what am concerned about that we could notice a wave of refugees!

MOAS Founder, Christopher Catrambone says: “Nobody has ever seen anything like what we are witnessing this weekend. (Continues)

Decreasing probability of < 100k based on latest numbers here: http://data2.unhcr.org/en/situations/mediterranean . 32k already in and we are 1/3 of the way into the year and have not hit the late summer seasonal spike yet.  However, the rate is not large enough to increase probability of more than 300k.

I'm making the assumption here that refugee and migrants flows will be similar to 2016, accounting for the migration deal with Turkey. Taking the numbers for the first three months and just adding the totals for the last nine months of 2016, I get 220,000 people. That's obviously an estimate I did in five minutes but luckily there's a range to the answer. My only concern is that the deal with Turkey could collapse but even if that happened I think it would be reestablished under more favorable terms to Turkey soon after.
The situations in conflict areas are not going prettier

Turkey will annul their agreement with the EU after they vote, which they do in April. A few hundred thousand refugees will then try to make the trip to Europe. This in addition to the migrants from Libya, where the human trafficking operations picking refugees up at the Libyan coast shows no signs of being prosecuted by the EU.
Second bucket up 15% for passage of time.
2014 was 500K, 2015 1,4M, less than a quarter of those from Syria. There is still no peace in Syria, and Africa is still poor, so no reason to expect a substantial decrease of refugees.

Looking at Jan. and Feb. data on http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/regional.html (7 and 10k, respectively), less than 100k seems improbable but possible depending on policy and more than 300k seems also improbable (required average of 28k p'm. for remainder) but possible depending on weather, support and policy.
It was over 130,000 by this time in 2016. It's 16,000 in 2017 by the end of February.

Current monthly rates put us under 100k, but they seem below average.  I don't fully understand the spike in 2015, nor why it tailed off. I think there is a modest probability (~25%) that it could happen again.
Gut feeling. Eyeing the graph. Expect similar results as in 2014. but expect strong variability.
12 355 arrivals by sea in 2017 in 2 months. At that rate, 74130 can be expected for full year. will recalculate as monthly data comes in, but clearly far less than the 362 376 that came in last year.
Land route safer and Turkey wants to poke Europe in the eye.

The reference given in the question is great. zero order estimate:  362k last year. 1st order estimate:  assume Jan numbers can be annualized: ~150k. yearly linear trend: 2015 1MM,   2016 362k ....linear model puts you below zero.  Need maybe exponential model and fitting to other refugee crises through the years.  Dump it into a 25% chance of < 100k. upper bound:  in 2015 there was a spike to 1MM.  Leave as possibility on upper end.

Initial forecast. Going with history modified for current conditions. European elections likely to depress willingness to open the borders in any sense. As we see, this question includes both N African and Aegean crossings.
